body:

I mean it's completely appropriate if you're trying to climb? There is no way to climb any significant amount besides "getting better".

Can you be a Silver 1 player and luck yourself into Gold 5? Sure. But a Silver 1 player will never "luck" into Gold 4/Gold 3. 

The problem is that people don't actually care about improving or continuing to climb - they just hope they can get lucky enough to get X desired rank (i.e. Gold 5). 

Whereas if they actually focused on improving, that rank would come naturally.

As someone who plays ranked only when LP gain/loss is nudging me up to the rank it wants me to be, I can say it's satisfying to see myself progress from being borderline Bronze 1 two years ago to being a solid Silver 5 and now being in Silver 4 just by improving and letting the system take me to where I belong.

The problem with recommending improvement is that it's a team game. In low elo, people who don't know what you're talking about will simply not listen to you. This happens in Challenger level games as well, if streams are anything to go by.

Telling someone they need to get better and they'll improve naturally comes off as snide, especially when you're ignoring that fact that you have a coinflip of having a team of delightful allies who run _with you,_ or a team of crying babies you have to drag to the finish line.

A Silver 1 player sure as hell can't luck their way into Gold 1, but a Plat 3 player sure as hell _can_ waffle between Gold 1 and Plat 5 if they get the wrong teammates.

It kind of does. I know the initial post was a bit of a rant, but let me elaborate.

Matchmaking is supposed to find players of equal-ish skill to compete against each other, however it gets more nuanced. Let's say it finds 10 people using silver 3 as a baseline, so you might have some silver 3's, 2's, 4's. Now it has to attempt to take the available player pool and sort them out. The system isn't going to take the 5 best people in the pool and put them on one side. So there is a balance. If a person is at the top of the pool and can be seen carrying the last 3+ games, then it would make sense to put the lowest player in the pool with them. Depending on how big the gap is the greater chance of discrepancy in the pool assignment.  So you might see something like this 1,4,7,8,10 vs 2,3,5,6,9. Which is sorting players by rank in the pool. It could be larger depending on how high number 1 is. So you could get a 1,5,8,9,10 vs 2,3,4,6,7. And that is a super easy win for the 2,3,4 side. A great example is a friend of mine that can hard carry. He will go on win streaks and then get something like this.

https://matchhistory.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/#match-details/NA1/2849453363/230306980?tab=overview

You can see where he will go on a win streak, then get a team that does that. The same happens to me. This game is still unfortunately about the worst player on the team having the most impact. But you can see this under Ranked in your profile. You don't really see many people on a hot streak. And it's why if you are on a win streak, you'll come across a game where you and one other player on the team are at the same skill level, if that.  

The problem which has been pointed out, is they allow people from different ranks into games they should not be in. This is where the system primarily fails. Especially in Silver where they can let first time ranked players end up in.

But before you say get better, there is any easy way to check match history and look at the stats, maybe there are merit to these words ;)

Anyway, your accusation is that league will intentionally give you worse players as allies as you go on a winstreak. That means initially, you can be paired up with anyone in your elo range. I honestly *want* to agree with you and say that the system is rigged, but that's simply just not how it works.

It's solo queue. People aren't going to pick optimal champions or even build a decent team comp every game. Some people will tilt. Some are already tilted from previous games, for the same reason that you're now upset at them.

Review the last 5 or so games of each of your teammates when you think Riot is "inting" your LP with their matchmaking. I seriously doubt that all four of your teammates are on a hard losing streak, or that they're inting/soft-inting all of their games. If they are, then that is the rarest case and will not consistently be happening to you.

Learn how to hard-win your role and to guide your team to victory. If you're 5/0 out of lane top as Darius and your bot is struggling. Go help them. If you're 1/4/2 as a jungler, then you're probably part of the problem and you need to figure out what is going wrong. Bad pathing? Counterjungling someone you can't fight? Counterjungling while enemy laners are missing and getting countered? Do you play support? Then all is not hopeless if your AD is having a rough game. Go roam and help the strongest part of your team and have your AD farm it out, and then bring the strongest part of your team to get your AD back into the game, while securing vision and denying vision to the enemy.

What usually makes the difference in the lower Elos is macro play and shot-calling, because players at these tiers just want to fight constantly and then don't know what to do after the fight is over. If you ace the enemy team at 20+ minutes, you get Baron if you are healthy enough or multiple towers, but I see lower Elo players base or go farm Krugs.

I've played at every division below Challenger on a variety of accounts over the years. If you put in the effort, you can come out ahead. Some games you will lose because the enemy team plays/drafts better than you, but you need to work on your gameplay because statistics completely disagree with your thinking. As much as you, and I, want it to be true that the system is broken, statistics don't lie.
